12. Fresco is not used here, unlike
what Michelangelo attributes to women,
since here in Holland, if outdoors,
it would hold up poorly against the harsh
Air, Wind, Snow, Hail, and Rain
driven by Boreas. Even inside, it cannot
endure or perhaps stay beautiful for very long
because of the great humidity of these walls.
left-middleFresco is not useful here, because of the Country’s humidity, and intemperate Weather.

13. Furthermore the Lime that is burned
from Seashells is of no use, for
it oozes and makes musty spots.
One should use limestone from other places
such as Tournai, or elsewhere,
which better resists bad storms and frost,
When used for painting, it is thick
and dries stiffly without mold

14. But passing over this: making cartoons
the same size as your work
is useful and practical if they are boldly
and clearly designed. They will appease
your work if you hang them
before you, lest you wander on unfamiliar paths
or lose sight of what is essential.
Darken and brighten everything, following the design.

15. Indeed, with the ground color darkened and brightened,
your cartoon must assume the character of a painting,
so that there is not the slightest imperfection in
standing out, shadowing, relief, rounding,
grace, flow, contrast, perspective:
and in your work, you must take care
not to tire easily, but ceaselessly long
to achieve, through effort, the greatest soundness.
left-middleCartoons must also have their highlights.

16. Our modern Predecessors worked on
their panels with white primer, more than we do;
and polished them as smoothly as they wished.
They also used cartoons, which they placed
on this even white layer, and laid down
with some dark/releasing substance rubbed on the back,
there they neatly retraced the drawing
with black chalks, or graphite.
left-middleThe moderns thickly whitened their panels, also using cartoons.

17. But the most effective was this: some took
black charcoal, delicately rubbed it with water, then dried it,
and carefully darkened their subjects as appropriate.
Then they neatly laid down a thin primer on top,
allowing one to see everything through it,
arranged with great forethought.
left-middleDrawing one’s subjects on the white, and laying an oily primer over it.
